key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal molecular and protein data with per-sample out-of-distribution (OOD) uncertainty estimation to produce more reliable binding-affinity predictions across multiple targets, improving trust and utility in polypharmacology modeling.
problem_solved: Current affinity predictors fail to quantify individual prediction reliability under distributional shifts (new compounds or targets), limiting their usefulness for polypharmacology where compounds interact with many proteins.
method: Fuse multimodal inputs (e.g., molecular representations, protein features, assay/context data) into a unified affinity prediction model.
Estimate individual-sample OOD uncertainty, flagging low-confidence predictions and calibrating scores for robust decision-making.
Use uncertainty-aware training/evaluation to improve generalization and ranking of compound–target affinities in polypharmacology scenarios.
impact: Gives ML practitioners a practical way to prioritize and triage affinity predictions with per-prediction confidence, reducing false leads and enabling safer, more efficient exploration of multi-target drug effects.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: multimodal inputs (molecule, protein, assay) → eMOSAIC model → affinity + per-sample uncertainty output
Calibration & OOD plot: reliability diagram or scatter showing better-calibrated predictions and separation of in-distribution vs OOD samples
Performance bar chart: comparative metrics (RMSE/AUC/precision@k) on in-distribution vs OOD test sets, highlighting gain from uncertainty filtering
Concept icon: molecule binding multiple proteins with confidence bars/traffic-light overlays to convey polypharmacology decisions
paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
